questions.text: Nitroglycerin causes all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Nitrates are commonly used anti-anginal drugs.

It is a better venodilator than an arteriolar dilator.

According to Merry’s law, Hypotension always follows by tachycardia and bradycardia is not seen. (Except in case of cardio-selective calcium channel blockers like Verapamil and Diltiazem where, hypotension followed by bradycardia is possible)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 586

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for use of verapamil?
questions.solution:
Contra indications for use of verapamil:

  1. With beta blocker (Cardioselective)
  2. 2nd and 3rd degree AV block
  3. WPW syndrome
  4. SA node dysfunction
  5. Lawn-Ganong-Levine syndrome
  6. Neuromuscular transmission deficieny

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 594

questions.text: A 75 yr old male patient known case of resistant CCF. Decided to start on digoxin, which of the following investigation is not necessary for follow up and initiation of therapy?
questions.solution:
Digoxin, a drug used for congestive cardiac failure (Never used as first line therapy), tend to be associated with following adverse effects

Non-cardiac:

  1. Anorexia
  2. Nausea/Vomiting
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Gynecomastia
  5. Xanthopsia

Cardiac:

  1. Non PSVT with variable heart block (Classic)

Majority is excreted unchanged by kidney, so monitoring liver function test is not necessary for initiation or for follow up of therapy with digoxin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 560

choices.text: Clonidine is a non-selective alpha 2 agonist drug
When given parenterally, it causes transient rise in BP
Moxonidine has more imidazoline activity than clonidine
It increases HDL and apoA1 and A2 levels

questions.text: Find the false statement regarding clonidine from the following:
questions.solution:
• Clonidine acts as an agonist at alpha 2 receptors (Non-selective)
  • When given IV, it causes transient rise in BP due to its α2b agonism
  • When given PO, it causes decrease in BP due to its α2a agonism
  • Moxonidine and Rilmenidine are clonidine derivatives with longer t ½ and more imidazoline activity than clonidine
  • Clonidine decrease HDL and apo A1 & A2 and has no major effect on other lipid molecules

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 611

questions.text: Polypeptide antibiotic bacitracin acts on:
questions.solution:
Drugs acting on cell wall of bacteria:

  1. Beta lactam (Penicillin, cephalosporin, Cabrapenem, monobactam)
  2. Fosfomycin
  3. Bacitracin
  4. Glycopeptide antibiotics (Vancomycin, Teicoplanin)
  5. Cycloserine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 809

questions.text: Which of the following beta lactam antibiotics can be safely used in a patient with history of allergy to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Drugs safely administered in patient allergic to penicillin:

Cell wall synthesis inhibitor:

  1. Vancomycin
  2. Aztreonam

Protein synthesis inhibitor:

  1. Macrolides
  2. Aminoglycosides (Genta / Tobra)
  3. Lincomsamides

Nucleic acid synthesis inhibitors:

  1. Fluoroquinolones
  2. Metronidazole

Folic acid synthesis inhibitors:

  1. Co-trim-oxazole

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 781

questions.text: Cephalosporin that does not require dose reduction in patient with any degree of renal impairment is:
questions.solution:
Cefoperazone (and ceftriaxone) is metabolized by liver and excreted via feces

Cefoperazone

It differs from other third generation compounds in having stronger activity on Pseudomonas and weaker activity on other organisms. Cefoperazone is good for S. typhi and B. fragilis also, but more susceptible to β-lactamases. The indications are - severe urinary, biliary, respiratory, skin-soft tissue infections, typhoid and septicaemias.

It is primarily excreted in bile; t½ is 2 hr. It has hypoprothrombinaemic action but does not affect platelet function. A disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol has been reported.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 778

questions.text: The ADR of aminoglycosides is lesser when given at which of the following dosing regimen?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides, being a drug which follows CDK (Concentration-dependant), with high adverse effect profile and low therapeutic index, is better opt to be administered as high dose extended interval regimen.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 796-797

questions.text: All of the following inhibits rate limiting step of aminoglycosides anti bacterial action Except:
questions.solution:
Factors than limit the activity of aminoglycosides:

  1. Hyperosmolar environment
  2. Acidic pH
  3. Presence of divalent cations
  4. Anerobic environment

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 793

choices.text: Does not inhibit hepatic microsomal enzymes
Eradicate mycoplasma infections in a single dose

questions.text: Advantage of clarithromycin over erythromycin is:
questions.solution:
Clarithromycin can be administered less frequently than erythromycin, but it is not effective in single doses against susceptible organisms. Organisms resistant to erythromycin, including pneumococci and methicillin-resistant staphylococci, are also resistant to other macrolides. Drug interactions have occurred with clarithromycin through its ability to inhibit cytochrome P450. Clarithromycin is more active than erythromycin against M avium complex, T gondii, and H pylori.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 803

questions.text: A 57 yr old chronic alcoholic develops hepatic encephalopathy. In an attempt to decrease his ammonia levels, you decide to sterilize his intestine. Which antibiotic can be given to accomplish this?
questions.solution:
Neomycin (an aminoglycoside) is not preferred to be given via parenteral route like other aminoglycosides due to its severe nephrotoxic potential. When given PO, it has least propensity to cross intestinal membranes and get absorbed, so, it acts locally as an anti-bacterial agent pertaining to intestines.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 799

choices.text: Decrease the dose to daily total of 200 mg
Maintain the patient on present dosage and test for auditory dysfunction
Decrease the dose to 180 mg every 8 h

questions.text: A 72 kg patient with creatinine clearance of 80 mL/min has a Gram -ve infection. Amikacin is administered intramuscularly at a dose of 5 mg/kg every 8 hrs and the patient begins to respond. After 2 days, creatinine clearance declines to 40 mL/min. Assuming that no information is available about amikacin plasma levels, what would be the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Monitoring plasma drug levels is important when aminoglycosides are used. In this case, the patient seems to be improving, so a decrease of the amikacin dose in proportion to decreased creatinine clearance is most appropriate. Because creatinine clearance is only one half of the starting value, a dose reduction should be made to one half of that given initially.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 796

questions.text: A 12 yr old boy presents with rash on palms and sole of his feet following a bite with a tick. His weil-Felix test is positive suggesting Rocky mountain spotted fever. Which of the following drugs should be given?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline, a tetracycline (30S ribosome inhibitor), is the antibiotic of choice to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a rickettsial disease. Streptomycin can be used to treat

plague and brucellosis. Bacitracin is only used topically. Ciprofloxacin can be used to treat anthrax, and erythromycin is the most effective drug for the treatment of Legionnaires

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 788

questions.text: A 4 yr old baby is brought to the casualty with an unknown tablet poisoning which was to be used for bacterial dysentery as per parent's history. The child had vomiting for more than 24 hrs and had diarrhoea with green stools. She is lethargic and an ashen colour skin. Also has hypothermia, hypotension and abdominal distention. Which drug is most likely to produce these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This is a case of chloramphenicol induced grey baby syndrome.

Classically seen due to its bone marrow toxicity ability.

Thiamphenicol and florphenicol does not produce bone marrow toxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 791

questions.text: Which of the following is a steroid antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Novobiocin – Aminocoumarin antibiotic

Bacitracin – Polypeptide antibiotic

Vancomycin – Glycopeptide antibiotic

Fusidic acid – Steroid antibiotic

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 809

questions.text: Fluoroquinolone with least oral bio availability is:
questions.solution:
Least PO bioavailability - Norfloxacin

Highest PO bioavailability - Levofloxacin


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 762

questions.text: Sparfloxacin and astemizole can cause:
questions.solution:
Other drugs causing torsades de pointes (Dancing around a point)

Zip dance in GTA

Zip -> Ziprasidone

Dance -> Torsades de pointes

G -> Grepafloxacin

T -> Terfenadine

A -> Astemizole

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 764

questions.text:
Folic acid metabolism is inhibited by:
1. Sulfonamides
2. Nitrous oxide
3. Methotrexate
4. Trimethoprim
5. 5-Flucytosine
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 756-921

questions.text: Supplementary folinic acid may prevent anemia in folate deficiency patients who use the following drug which is a weak base:
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim is the only weak base listed (fluoroquinolones and sulfonamides are acidic compounds), and its high lipid solubility at blood pH allows penetration of the drug into prostatic and vaginal fluid to reach levels similar to those in plasma. Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia may occur in folate deficiency when the drug is used alone or in combination with sulfamethoxazole. Fluoroquinolones and linezolid do not exacerbate symptoms of folic acid deficiency

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 758

questions.text: Synergism is seen for flucytosine when given along with
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B -> Drug that targets fungal cell wall

Flucytosine -> Drug that affect fungal nucleic acids

Sows synergism when given together.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 841

questions.text: Drug penetration into CNS is restricted by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
• More the lipophilicity of a drug, more the penetration of CNS by the drug
  • P-glycoprotein actively cause efflux of drug and actively pumps drug out of CNS
  • Inflammation causes disruption of blood brain barrier, which makes the penetration easier
  • Uptake transporters are proposed as one of the major mechanisms of drug transport across BBB.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 19-24

questions.text: Chloroquine is given as 600 mg loading dose because:
questions.solution:
Chloroquine, an antimalarial drug, has got the highest volume of distribution which makes it more tissue bounded than other drugs.

It also has a selective distribution to ocular fluids, which is responsible for its Bull’s eye maculopathy adverse effect.

Due to its, high volume of distribution, it has to be administered as loading dose and that dose needs to be maintained too.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 880

questions.text: Disulfiram like reaction is seen with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Drugs showing disulfiram:

GCS POST MORTEM

G – Griseofulvin

C – Cephalosporins (Cefotetan, perezone, mandole)

S – Sulfonyl ureas

Post – Procarbazine

Mortem - Metronidazole

Satranidazole -> Does not show Disulfiram like reactions

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 897

questions.text: Which of the following drugs tend to produce this adverse reaction?
questions.solution:
Diethyl carbamazine:

ADR:

  • Pruritis
  • Giddiness
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Mazzotti reaction -> Reaction of skin and eyes in Onchocerciasis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 911

questions.text: Match the drug with its adverse effect:
questions.solution:
Abacavir -> HS reactions (HLA B 5701) -> Stop therapy

Nevirapine -> Fatal hepatitis -> More hepatitis if started in patients with more CD4 count

Atazanavir -> Asymptomatic reversible unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Stavudine -> Maximum lactic acidosis among all ARV drugs (Due to mitochondrial toxicity)

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 1251-1253

questions.text: A patient was receiving insulin and acarbose for diabetes mellitus and developed hypoglycaemia. Which of the following should be used as a treatment of hypoglycaemia for this patient?
questions.solution:
As this patient is on treatment with Acarbose (an alpha glucosidase inhibitor), the polysaccharides given for this patient is not converted to monocaccharides for its absorption.

Even though hypoglycemia is less common with use of alpha glucosidase inhibitor, as patient is on Insulin, this might provoke hypoglycemia.

But, administering Polysaccharides via PO route is not going to treat hypoglycemia as its not going to  be absorbed due to the action of acarbose.

PO monosaccharides (Glucose) OR parenteral glucose can be used as treatment for this patient.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 296

choices.text: It can be used for treatment of Type II diabetes mellitus
It has dual activity both of GLP-1 and GLP-2

questions.text: All statements about Semaglutide are true except
questions.solution:
Semaglutide:

  • GLP-1 analogue
  • First PO GLP-1 analogue for treatment of T2DM

Teduglutide:

  • GLP-2 analogue
  • Approved for Short bowel syndrome

Apraglutide

  • Selective GLP-2 agonist
  • Under trial

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 1038-1039

questions.text:
All of the following is/are used as P.O therapy for both T1DM and T2DM EXCEPT:
1. Dapagliflozin
2. Sotagliflozin
3. Pramlintide
4. Vildagliptin
questions.solution:
Therapy for both T1DM and T2DM:

  1. Pramlintide - S.C
  2. Dapagliflozin - P.O
  3. Sotagliflozin - P.O

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 293

questions.text: All of these can be used for post coital contraception except
questions.solution:
Drugs for post coital contraception:

drink MILO after Unprotected sex

M -> Mifepristone

I -> Intra uterine devices

L -> Levonorgesterol

O -> Oral contraceptive pills

U -> Ulipristal

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 348

questions.text: Which of these is an appropriate starting dose regimen for sildenafil in pulmonary arterial hypertension?
questions.solution:
Sildenafil:

  • PDE-5 inhibitor
  • Used for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • Initially started with 20 mg TDS

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 328

choices.text: It is a competitive angiotensin receptor antagonist
It has a long acting metabolite

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding losartan?
questions.solution:
Losartan

  • Angiotensin receptor blocker
  • Has long t 1.2 due to a long acting metabolite
  • It has no effect on levels of bradykinin, so it does not produce cough.
  • This has additional uricouric property.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 535

choices.text: Are suitable for use in conjunction with a beta blocker or digoxin
Cause a much higher incidence of reflex tachycardia
Cause significant dose-dependent slowing of AV nodal conduction velocity

questions.text: We want to compare the cardiac and hemodynamic profiles of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers and non-dihydropyridines. The most striking difference is that compared with nifedipine, Verapamil and diltiazem?
questions.solution:
The dihydropyridines are relatively selective for their vascular effects.

- Cause significant arteriolar dilation

- Hypotension

- Reflex +ve Ionotropic/Chronotropic/Dromotropic activity on heart.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 593

questions.text: Alkalinisation of urine ameliorates the toxicity of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is an acidic drug (Folic acid analogue) which inhibits the activity of DHFR. In case of overdose or toxicity, alkalinisation of urine tends to increase the excretion of methotrexate.

Glucarpidase is a specific antidote for methotrexate poisoning, which serves as a methotrexate cleaving enzyme.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 989

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is extracted from this plant source?
questions.solution:
This is Camptotheca acuminate. From which Irinotecan is extracted.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 925-926

choices.text: Alternative anti-coagulant such as danaparoid/Fondaparinux should be administered
Low molecular weight heparins should be avoided
Heparin should be replaced with warfarin

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is incorrect about heparin induced thrombocytopenia:
questions.solution:
Heparin induced thrombocytopenia:

  • Both Unfractionated and low molecular weight heparin causes thrombocytopenia (Incidence is less with LMWH)
  • Lepirudin/Danaparoid/Fondaparinux can be administered instead of heparin
  • Heparin replacement with warfarin is not recommended during treatment of a patient with HIT.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 665

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs has maximum oral BA?
questions.solution: Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 735

questions.text: A laboratory study of new H2 blocker is planned. Which of the following will result from blockade of H2 receptors?
questions.solution:
Histaminic receptors:

H1 -> Gq -> Stimulates PLC -> Increases IP3/DAG

H2 -> Gs -> Stimulates AC -> Increases cAMP

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 696

choices.text: Exhibit no changes in fexofenadine elimination
Be at risk of developing torsades de pointes, due to decreased metabolism of fexofenadine
Decreased elimination of fexofenadine, without manifestation of torsades de pointes

questions.text: A patient takes fexofenadine 60 mg BD for seasonal allergies. He comes to the doctor with sinusitis and receives a prescription of erythromycin (Drug that inhibits CYP3A4). As a result of this drug interaction, You expect the patient to
questions.solution:
Fexofenadine is a third-generation anti-histaminic agent which is excreted unchanged via feces. Erythromycin being a microsomal enzyme inhibitor, will propose no major changes in metabolism and excretion of fexofenadine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 181

questions.text: A 57 yr old man has severe pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following agent causes vasodilation and may be useful in pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Prostacyclin (PGI2) is the prostaglandin which causes maximum vasodilation.

Prostacyclin analogues:

  1. Epoprostenol
  2. Iloprostenol
  3. Treprostenol

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 207-546

choices.text: Ethanol induces p450 enzymes that form toxic metabolite

questions.text: In a person who regularly consume ethanol daily, the potential for hepatotoxicity due to paracetamol is greater than normal. What is the most likely explanation for this?
questions.solution:
Paracetamol on metabolism produces non-toxic (Major) and some toxic (minor but highly reactive) metabolite named NAPBQI. Chronic alcoholics tend to behave as microsomal enzyme inducers which makes more of paracetamol to be metabolized to the toxic metabolite thereby increasing chances of hepatotoxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 419

choices.text: Sucralfate decreases the absorption of famotidine
Sucralfate increases the toxicity of famotidine
Sucralfate decreases the absorption of antacids
Sucralfate polymerizes only when gastric pH is less than 4

questions.text: A patient is taking famotidine, sucralfate and antacid tablets. Why is this combination irrational?
questions.solution:
Sucralfate (SUCrose sulFATE and ALuminium hydroxide):

In acidic environment of stomach, the aluminium moiety is released, so that the compound develops a strong negative charge and binds positively charged protein molecules that transude from damaged mucosa.

This results in a viscous paste that adheres selectively and protectively to ulcer base.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 704

choices.text: It decreases the intestinal transit time
It is a Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor
It increases the conversion of ATP to cAMP

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is true regarding racecadotril?
questions.solution:
Racecadotril:

  • Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor
  • Increases half-life of enkephalins
  • Decreases conversion of ATP to cAMP
  • Does not alter intestinal transit time
  • Does not produce constipation or bloating

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 733

questions.text: Which of the following thiazide diuretic has additional vasodilatory property?
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 607

questions.text: A 62 yr old man with advanced prostate cancer is admitted in the ICU with mental obtundation. An electrolyte panel shows a serum calcium of 16.5 (normal 8.5 to 10.5 mg/dL). Which of the following therapies would be most useful in management of severe hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
CA and K+ sparing diuretics -> Metabolic acidosis

Loop diuretics and thiazide diuretics -> Metabolic alkalosis.

Diuretic therapy of hypercalcemia requires a reduction in calcium reabsorption in the thick ascending limb, an effect of loop diuretics. However, a loop diuretic alone would reduce blood volume around the remaining calcium so that serum calcium would not decrease appropriately. Therefore, saline infusion should accompany the loop diuretic

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 628

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct answer as per picture depicted:

1. A - Dependant on PPB
2. C - Thiazide diuretics site of action
3. B - Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors site of action
4. D - Triamterene opens a channel
questions.solution:
A -> Glomerular filtration -> Highly plasma protein bound drugs are not filtered via glomerulus, only free drugs are filtered

B -> Thich ascending limb of loop of Henle -> Area of action for Loop diuretics (not carbonic anhydrase inhibitors)

C -> Distal convoluted tubule -> Thiazide diuretics act at this site

D -> Collecting duct -> Triamterene is an epithelial sodium channel blocker

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 633-635

questions.text: The drug which enhances slow inactivation of voltage gated Na+ channels is
questions.solution:
Lacosamide is the only drug which enhances slow inactivation of voltage gated Na+ channels, whereas the other drugs tend to enhance fast inactivation of Na+ channels.

Lacosamide also binds and inhibits Collapsin Response Mediator Protein – 2 (CRMP-2)

(CRMP-2 involved in neuronal differentiation and axonal outgrowth)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 447

questions.text: This adverse effect associated with use of which of the following drug?
questions.solution:
Phenytoin -> Due to high lipid solubility -> when given parenterally, might cause distal ischemia causing purple glove syndrome.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 441

questions.text: 28 yr old complaints of joint pain for past 1 week. On investigation, his uric acid levels are raised. Which of the following drugs would not have caused this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Drugs causing hyperuricemia:

PEN AND CYCLE INCREASES URINE

P -> Pyrazinamide

E -> Ethambutol

N -> Nicotinic acid

AND -> Aspirin (Low dose), Alcohol

Cycle -> Cyclosporine, cytotoxic drugs

Increases urine -> Diuretics (Thaizide and loop)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 637-638

choices.text: He must continue allopurinol throughout life
3 months after achieving target serum uric acid levels
6 months after achieving target serum uric acid levels
1 yr after achieving target serum uric acid levels

questions.text: 50 yr old diagnosed as acute gout without tophi was managed successfully. He was started on long term Urate lowering therapy with Allopurinol as a prophylaxis of acute gout. Which of the following conditions warrant to stop allopurinol for the patient?
questions.solution:
Prophylaxis of acute gout with ULT:

  • Atleast 6 month duration
  • Acute gout without tophi: 3 months after achieving target SUA
  • Acute gout with tophi: 6 months after achieving target SUA

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 234-235

choices.text: QT prolongation with tall T waves

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common ECG finding in patients treated with lithium?
questions.solution:
ECG changes with lithium:

Most common – Inverted / Flattened T waves

Also – Sinus node dysfunction, Sinoatrial blocks, PR/QT prolongation, Ventricular arrhythmia

Rare – STEMI, Brugada pattern.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 476-477
